bestBHT.bht: The man in question had endured a debilitating infirmity for an astonishing period of thirty-eight years, rendering him unable to walk. The exact nature of his affliction remains unknown, only that it was long-standing and likely regarded as incurable. Despite seeking solace at the pool of Bethesda, its healing properties had ceased due to the Israelites' blasphemy. In the face of hopelessness and desperation, it was through the agency of Christ that his cure was manifested, emphasizing the power and intervention of Christ in his healing.

Henry Alford: 5.] Observe, he had been lame thirty-eight years, not at Bethesda all that time.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: not all that time at the pool. This was probably the most pitiable of
all the cases, and therefore selected.
Albert Barnes: An infirmity - A weakness. We know not what his disease was.
We know only that it disabled him from walking, and that it was of very long standing.
It was doubtless regarded as incurable.
Marvin Vincent: Had an infirmity thirty and eight years. Literally, having thirty and eight years in his infirmity.
John Calvin: The long duration of the disease had taken away all hope of its being cured.
There was no man to assist him, and this causes the power of Christ to be more strikingly displayed.
Such, too, was the import of the command to carry his bed, that all might plainly see that he was cured in no other way than by the agency of Christ.
Philip Schaff: This sufferer had endured thirty-eight years of weakness.
How long he had been wont to resort to Bethesda we cannot tell.
It may have been only for days or even hours.
Archibald T. Robertson: Which had been thirty and eight years (τριακοντα κα οκτω ετη εχων). Literally, "having thirty and eight years," "having spent thirty and eight years."
John Gill: He was one of the weak, or impotent folk, for so he is called.
Nor indeed can it be known how long there had been such a preternatural motion in this pool, and such a miraculous virtue in the water.

The pool of Bethesda was useful in curing the diseases of the Israelites; but ceased from yielding any benefit, when the name of the Lord was blasphemed by them, through their rage and fury, and continuance in it.

bhtAttempts.bht: The man in John 5:5 had been suffering from his infirmity for an extensive period of time, specifically thirty-eight years. Although it is unclear what exactly his disease entailed, it had left him unable to walk for a considerable portion of his life and was likely deemed incurable. This lengthy and hopeless situation is what made his case particularly pitiable. The man, unable to find any assistance, had resorted to the pool of Bethesda, though it is uncertain how long he had been doing so. However, the pool itself had lost its effectiveness due to the Israelites' blasphemy, causing its miraculous healing properties to cease. It was under these circumstances of desperation and disbelief that the power of Christ was made all the more remarkable.

The man in question had endured a debilitating infirmity for an astonishing period of thirty-eight years, rendering him unable to walk. The exact nature of his affliction remains unknown, only that it was long-standing and likely regarded as incurable. Despite seeking solace at the pool of Bethesda, its healing properties had ceased due to the Israelites' blasphemy. In the face of hopelessness and desperation, it was through the agency of Christ that his cure was manifested, emphasizing the power and intervention of Christ in his healing.

The man in question had suffered from his infirmity for an extensive period of time, a total of thirty-eight years. Although the details of his disease remain unknown, what is evident is his inability to walk and the longevity of his condition. It is highly likely that his ailment was deemed incurable. Seeking relief, he frequented the pool of Bethesda, but its once miraculous healing powers had ceased due to the Israelites' blasphemy. It is within this context of despair that the intervention of Christ shines brightly.

For a staggering thirty-eight years, the man in question had been burdened by his infirmity, rendering him incapable of walking. Though the specifics of his ailment remain unknown, it is evident that it was long-standing and likely deemed incurable. Seeking solace at the pool of Bethesda, he hoped for healing. Regrettably, the pool's miraculous powers had ceased due to the Israelites' blasphemy. It is in this desperate state that Christ's intervention surpasses human expectations and demonstrates its divine origin.

Having endured his infirmity for an incredible thirty-eight years, the man had found himself unable to walk. The nature of his affliction remains unknown, but its chronicity and debilitating effects are clear. He sought relief at the pool of Bethesda, yet its miraculous healing properties had ceased due to the blasphemy of the Israelites. In this dark context, the miraculous intervention of Christ shines brightly, demonstrating His power to bring healing where all hope seemed lost.
